conclusion: At steady state the capacitor is an open circuit (no dc current through it).

premise: At steady state the capacitor is an open circuit (no dc current through it).
conclusion: The branch containing the capacitor and R₂ is therefore open; only the branch containing R₁ and R₃ carries current supplied by the source.

premise: The branch containing the capacitor and R₂ is therefore open; only the branch containing R₁ and R₃ carries current supplied by the source.
conclusion: The current I flowing from the source is found from the series resistance R₁ + R₃ together with the source’s internal resistance r: Req = r + R₁ + R₃ = 2 Ω + 2 Ω + 6 Ω = 10 Ω

premise: Req = r + R₁ + R₃ = 2 Ω + 2 Ω + 6 Ω = 10 Ω
conclusion: I = E / Req = 6 V / 10 Ω = 0.60 A

The potential difference between the two horizontal nodes (i.e. the voltage across the open branch where the capacitor sits) equals the drop across R₁ (because R₁ is between the same two nodes): Vnode = I · R₁ = 0.60 A × 2 Ω = 1.2 V
This node-to-node voltage is the voltage across the capacitor after a long time, so Q = C · V = (10 μF)(1.2 V) = 12 μC
